<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><record_update table="x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases"> <x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases action="INSERT_OR_UPDATE"> <common_name>Powdery mildew (Erysiphe graminis)</common_name> <description>How does Powdery mildew (Erysiphe graminis) occur? Powdery mildew reproduces through sexual reproduction, forming fruiting bodies called cleistothecia that release spores. These spores can be carried by wind or other means to infect susceptible plants. Additionally, it reproduces asexually by producing conidia, which are airborne spores formed on the powdery growth of infected plants. These conidia can spread to new hosts, initiating new infections, and facilitating the rapid dissemination of the disease.
</description> <family/> <host>all lawn grasses,</host> <number>PLD0001006</number> <scientific_name>Erysiphe graminis</scientific_name> <solution>Application of Fungicides In severe cases or when preventive measures are insufficient. Azoxystrobin, propiconazole (BumperÂ® 250 EC), tebuconazole, myclobutanil (Orius 250 EW), fenarimol, difenoconazole, cyprodinil, and flutriafol are examples of synthetic fungicides effective against this fungus.
Sulfur-based fungicides and Biofungicides based on Bacillus subtilis can also be used against this. Adhere to the instructions and apply them as directed.
</solution> <sys_class_name>x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases</sys_class_name> <sys_created_by>admin</sys_created_by> <sys_created_on>2024-10-21 23:05:49</sys_created_on> <sys_id>632d9ecb975112109790fefce053af86</sys_id> <sys_mod_count>1</sys_mod_count> <sys_updated_by>admin</sys_updated_by> <sys_updated_on>2024-10-21 23:06:33</sys_updated_on> </x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases> </record_update>
